private_information: I am agent robot1 and can pick up one top block at a time
I can perform unstack, stack, pickup, and putdown actions following BlocksWorld rules
robot1.goal: Execute assigned block manipulation steps and report a local action trace consistent with the BlocksWorld rules

private_information: I am agent robot2 and can pick up one top block at a time
I can perform unstack, stack, pickup, and putdown actions following BlocksWorld rules
robot2.goal: Execute assigned block manipulation steps and report a local action trace consistent with the BlocksWorld rules

private_information: I coordinate robot1 and robot2 and must produce a final PDDL domain and problem
The final PDDL must target the FastDownwards solver and keep actions distinct per agent
orchestrator.goal: Integrate the agents' local traces and produce a complete PDDL domain and problem file for FastDownwards that represents the final arrangement after the given action sequence

init.rules_summary: Only the top block of a stack can be moved. Only one block can be carried at a time. Legal actions are unstack(X,Y), stack(X,Y), pickup(X), putdown(X).

public_information: There are eight blocks: A B C D E F G H.
Initial arrangement: A is on the table, B is on top of A, C is on top of H, D is on top of E, E is on top of B, F is on top of C, G is on the table, H is on top of G.
BlocksWorld rules apply: only the top block of a stack can be moved and only one block can be carried at a time.
Available actions are unstack, stack, pickup, and putdown.

plan.system_prompt: You are robot1. Observe the public information and the sequence of world actions. Do not emit PDDL. Provide a clear step by step local action trace and any local observations about which moves you can perform given BlocksWorld rules. If some information is missing, report the uncertainty instead of assuming values.
plan.prompt: Your name is robot1. You have the following public information: {environment->public_information}. You have the following private knowledge: {agents->robot1->private_information}. Your goal: {agents->robot1->goal}. Consider the global action sequence and state changes and produce a local ordered list of actions you would perform and the local state after each action.

plan.system_prompt: You are robot2. Observe the public information and the sequence of world actions. Do not emit PDDL. Provide a clear step by step local action trace and any local observations about which moves you can perform given BlocksWorld rules. If some information is missing, report the uncertainty instead of assuming values.
plan.prompt: Your name is robot2. You have the following public information: {environment->public_information}. You have the following private knowledge: {agents->robot2->private_information}. Your goal: {agents->robot2->goal}. Consider the global action sequence and state changes and produce a local ordered list of actions you would perform and the local state after each action.

pddl.system_prompt: You are the orchestrator. Integrate the agents' local traces and produce a single PDDL domain and a single PDDL problem that represent the final world state after the given action sequence. The PDDL must be compatible with the FastDownwards solver. Keep actions of robot1 and robot2 distinct by naming action operators with agent prefixes if needed. Always enclose the PDDL domain between <domain></domain> tags and the PDDL problem between <problem></problem> tags.
pddl.prompt: You are orchestrator. Use the public information and the agents' reported local traces to derive the final arrangement of the blocks after the following action sequence: 1. unstack(D,E) 2. stack(D,F) 3. unstack(E,B) 4. putdown(E) 5. unstack(D,F) 6. putdown(D) 7. unstack(B,A) 8. stack(B,E) 9. unstack(B,E) 10. stack(B,A) 11. unstack(F,C) 12. putdown(F) 13. unstack(B,A) 14. stack(B,E) 15. pickup(A) 16. putdown(A) 17. pickup(D) 18. putdown(D) 19. unstack(C,H) 20. stack(C,F). Integrate the agents' inputs: {plan_robot1} and {plan_robot2}. Do not assume unspecified facts. Produce a PDDL domain and a PDDL problem for FastDownwards that capture the final arrangement. Enclose the domain between <domain></domain> and the problem between <problem></problem>.
